1110182792443449344.text:
Focusing on a metric like participation rate to assess governance is a mistake. 

1) addresses != to people, so difficult to calculate correctly 
2) votes are stake weighted, not address weighted
3) a participation rate says nothing about quality of governance

1093498629665550336.text: That's a quick brain dump. If you can think of any other, plz tell me!

1093498627555770368.text: 7/ Legal structures you can easily attach to a DAO: Crypto natives dislike bureaucracy, and they will turn to DAOs to escape it. A smart jurisdiction would recognize the trend and ride the wave

1093498625219575808.text: 6/ Modern laws on data storage: Running Bitcoin, Ethereum or IPFS nodes may get you intro trouble in some countries, as those networks have copyrighted material or illegal porn on them. But that doesn't mean you should get in trouble

1093498622929498112.text: 5/ No ISP surveillance: Countries like Switzerland already have very strict rules that disallow ISPs to spy on citizens. Advanced crypto natives may already use Tor or VPNs, but most people don't

1093498620563853312.text: 4/ Low residency requirement: Crypto natives are remote-first, meaning that they may not even have a permanent residency and may spend a few days here and there

1093498618437357574.text: 3/ Secure tax reporting systems: If people are their own bank, that also means they can get kidnapped and robbed. Not having 1,000 eyes look on your tax return, and having them all securely stored should be a must

1093498615870472193.text: 2/ No privacy invasion: Laws that force citizens to give out their private keys or secrets under an investigation or while being detained need to be completely abolished

1093498613349662725.text: 1/ No cap gains: It's not even a matter of paying taxes or not, but it's close to impossible to keep track of all monetary transactions in Web3. We are close to a world in which we use Web3 everyday, and that implies thousands of transactions per year

1093498611068030976.text: Jurisdictional competition is still in its infancy, but it will accentuate as crypto gets bigger and captures more value. A thread on how nation states can attract crypto natives

Then why does it makes sense to introduce messy governance for protocol upgrades, but not for producing blocks as well?

1075091574604918784.text: 7/ Taxes are not only the money you pay to the government. But also the time you spend on their obsolete legal systems. Smart contracts stop that absurdity. Fin

1075091573153640454.text: 6/ Smart contracts can seem a toy if you look at them isolated. But if you are experienced with legal matters (specially cross-jurisdiction), you will notice how they could re-shape society completely

1075090570278780928.text: 5/ Smart contracts can be audited, and auditors can have on-chain skin in the game to guarantee a secure execution, as its creator intended. Legal contracts are created and audited by legal firms with no skin in the game at all

1075090568726962176.text: 4/ Smart contracts need to be open sourced and publicly audited for them to be trusted. Legal contracts are kept closed, and law firms are incentivized to keep them that way so their business model stays defensible

1075090563496587264.text: 3/ Ethereum has a virtual machine, and you can inspect its codebase and be certain of the way a contract will be executed. The legal system has infinite paperwork, secured by pen signatures that can be easily tampered with

1075090561118470144.text: 2/ Ethereum has sound cryptoeconomic incentives in place so things are  executed the way they should be. The legal system has opaque incentives and patchworks, so you are never 100% certain how things will play out

1075090559361056773.text: 1/ Smart contracts give you strong guarantees of the execution of an agreement. Legal contracts, specially across multiple jurisdictions, give you a very remote sense of how things may be executed

1075090557708525570.text: The legal system is broken, and I'm marveled that our world even works today. Thread
